Best Tapas in Madison!   My wife and I will try to make it here a couple times a year for date nights. They have a wonderful wine selection, large menu of appetizers and always a few specials. Service is amazing, some of the best in Madison.

After eating roughly half the menu and drinking one of the tastiest dark and stormy's I have ever had (the "daq and stormy"), I am pretty well convinced that this is one of the best places to eat in the Madison area.  We had: goat cheese pastries, bruschetta, truffled fries, portabella mushroom ravioli, stuffed piquillo peppers, sea bass and scallops, chicken skewers, braised pork belly, center cut fillet, and a Thai chicken flat bread.   Every single thing we had was delicious, but there were definitely a few standouts. For me, the braised pork belly, the ravioli, and the Thai chicken flat bread were the best of the night. I would seriously eat a pound of that pork belly.   The service was great, the atmosphere was relaxing, and the water food was great. I will definitely be back for more!

Not really impressed with the food or wine list. The idea of the ipad for wine list is crazy!   You can't look for it he right wine and the options are very limited. It should not be called a wine bar since there is nothing special about the wine they carry.   We ordered the seared tuna, green beans, flatbread and the battered shrimp. The tuna and green beans were pretty decent but the rest of the food was just below average. I do like the comparison from other teloera saying that it is very comparable to an overpriced Applebee's with wine.   I also noticed that the menu has not changed in over three years. The desserts are also terrible!

The Applebee's of tapas bars.  The Chili's of wine bars.  The food is almost on par with Alchemy or Mickey's Tavern, but the pricing is 2x-2.5x.  Atmosphere: televisions, noise on par with Weary Traveler, and fat, old men pawing 20-something women.  Service: seated immediately, waited 25 minutes to get water and put in first drink order; waitress kept on trying to steer the meal in very odd directions ("order an extra one to take home").   Off the specials menu we ordered a lovely chorizo white bean soup that was the high point of the meal; it would have been even better if the tomato base had the taste you'd expect at the peak of tomato season and the black pepper had been reduced to allow other flavors to shine a bit more. Next we had pleasant stuffed peppers, which had very nice presentation and not much to remember in terms of mouth feel or taste.  The Thai flatbread pizza was the blandest item of the evening; coleslaw should not be more engaging than the accompanying jalapenos.  Our Spanish red was quite nice.  A place billing itself as a wine bar should have more than one Spanish red, especially when its manager was hired from the former La Paella.  The wine menu is not available on paper or on your cell phone. They provide one iPad per table for marking wine selection.  This works great for the restaurant, but is cumbersome for patrons (the larger your group, the more unmanageable it becomes).  If you want wine, go to Barriques.  If you want tapas, Madison's pickings are slim.  If you want better food at half the price, Madison's offerings abound.

I have been coming to Eno Vino off and on (been in and out of the state for years) for about 5 years!  I've always loved this place!  First off: they have one of the most amazing selections of wine AND liquor I've seen from any place I've been to in Wisconsin, Hawaii and all over Europe.  They have not only a good variety, but all good-quality liquor.  They don't waste their time with the crap.  Second, they have well-made drinks (mostly martinis) and the service and ambiance is very nice.  I often get the Espresso Martini, and I've never found a restaurant that does an Espresso Martini that well!  They have excellent Portobello Ravioli as well as Spicy Calamari.  These are foods you can find elsewhere, but they do the same or much better here (the Ravioli is unique and absolutely wonderful!)  As of a year or so ago, they've expanded the restaurant to give it about 20-30% more floor area.  That's very nice, especially for nights when it's packed (Wednesdays and Thursdays tend to be busy).  I always come back!!!    -  Jordan www.freshphotography.us

Tapas......oh tapas.....  The good the bad and the ugly:  Everything we ordered (minus the chicken satay) were all impeccable.....but the wait in between got my mouth watering so much for the next dish that it was hard to contain myself.   it was also too bad that our dinner-mates that opted to go sans-tapas and more the traditional entree course were left waiting with empty plates while we were delivered several dishes.    The delicateness of the oxtail strudel, the delicious bruchetta, fried spicy calamari, were amazing. The tuna tartare was not impressive and the chocolate fondue was just plain chocolate syrup. $16 for lukewarm chocolate syrup was ridiculous.   Although we extremely disliked a few things.....at least we know now what to avoid and we will definitely be back because the dishes we DID like......were AMAZING!  And well worth another trip!

Yay for a Madison Tapas Place!!!!!!!!!  This is THE BEST restaurant for excellent wine, really good portion tapas, and just all around ambiance.  I WILL say that I give it two thumbs down in their food selection, given that it's VERY vegetarian unfriendly.  But seriously their extensive wine list pretty much makes up for this!!!!  Wait staff is very courteous and well.. if you're in a good group, this is great to sample a ton of things.  However, this brings on the classic case scenario of the people who "just want to pay for what they bought (regardless of the fact that they ate from another plate" or the ones that "forget" that tipping is important.... But that's a story for another day...

The five star is for the braised brisket and everything on the side. Frankly I don't care if the brussel sprouts were fried; they were done so deliciously and I could taste hint of cheese in the sweet potatoes mash but I love it. I want more sprouts please.  The bruschetta aren't as tasty as I remember maybe because the bread was toasted more this time. I could be that I'm exhausted with training and work after.  Would I come back? Absolutely.  Kirsten seems shy but maybe she could see that I'm dining alone and perhaps wanted to be left alone. She checked on me and I don't ask for more than that.

Hands down my favorite restaurant in the Madison area. My husband and I even had our wedding dinner here. Our favorite dishes are the charred hot house tomato soup, truffled fries, seared sesame tuna, lamb empanadas, and Korean short rib potstickers. The wine and cocktail selections are always fun and change pretty regularly. My one complaint, however, is that their dessert menu used to change seasonally (which we really liked), but they stopped doing that over the last year or two. We recently moved to Seattle, and I'm still trying to find our Eno Vino replacement!

I went there on a Wednesday night with a friend and we ordered probably 6 different dishes on their happy hour menu. I would say that the service was super slow and then when the dishes came through there were problems with a majority of them. We ordered the ahi tuna tacos which were super salty, the calamari fries were more batter than calamari, and the shrimp ceviche was way too sour which we informed the waitress but instead of offering to bring us a new plate or remove it from our tab she just took the plate back. I would never ever come back to this place again and I would not recommend anyone else to try this.

A true five star experience in every way. I can't complain about a thing - the atmosphere is modern, appropriately soft lighted, and that perfect balance of quiet, but not too quiet. The service is fantastic. The waitstaff are knowledgeable, prompt, and attentive. Then there's the food.   Oh god, there's the food.   The food is a cool selection of modern takes on American cuisine. Most of the plates are smaller and easy to share, and everything we've tried was excellent. I have to give a specific shout-out to the Hot House Tomato Soup, though. It is maybe the best soup I've ever had. The taste of real truffle oil and Wisconsin cheddar surround your mouth with savory, tangy, salty, cheesy, perfection. You also get an entire grilled cheese sandwich in your soup, so definitely grab a friend to share if you want to taste the rest of the menu!

-Great ambiance - romantic, beautiful, dark colors, gentle lighting. Too bad it is destroyed by giant sports TV screens! -Terrible service - had to flag down a waiter after being ignored for a long time. Seriously? -Wine bar? - NO, they don't get it. The server didn't have much to say about the wines I guess because she left an iPad on the table with info about the wines on it! NO - I am in a wine bar for god's sake, service and knowledge are expected, not a computer where I have to search and such! LAZY SERVICE.  -Ordered a wine flight and had to ask for bread to clear the palate - the worst isthat I asked specifically for "plain bread" and was given some crazy bread full of I don't know what nuts and fruits and a spread full of other flavors! Does this place not "get" wine tasting at all?? So I then asked the bus boy to bring me plain unflavored bread! (finally received some) Ridunkulous. -Lastly - two huge TV screens  were showing SPORTS - in a WINE bar!! Seriously? That ruined the otherrwise great decor. HINT TO MANAGEMENT: 1. Servers at a wine bar should have some knowledge about wine. 2. Sports bars and wine bars are not expected to be the same in any way.

I didn't take pictures of my yummy food because it was dark at the bar, but the food and the service are excellent at Eno Vino.  I was directed there by friends who had previously been.  It's slightly hidden in the corner of a mini-mall, but the space is deceptively big for such a small entrance.  I had a green salad with balsamic dressing, ahi tuna tacos and a bruschetta duo of salmon & roast beef.  The ahi tuna tacos are served on a crunchy shell with a dab of a creamy wasabi and a sweet chili sauce.  Those were awesome.  The good is great, but I was kind of limited because everything is small dishes and I easily hit my corporate dining max.  It's probably way more fun to bring a friend & share.  I'll be back!

Truffle. Fries. That is basically all I need to say here. I moved here from Boston, so I will say that this definitely more of a "Midwestern" tapas place. Not in the sense that the food is midwestern, but the portions are a bit big. This is NOT a negative against the restaurant - (um, more truffle fries please!) just keep this in mind when you're ordering here. The cocktails are FANTASTIC and cheap! Thankfully, this please is around the corner from where we live, so we frequently go here when we're in the mood for something a little on the fancier side.   Whatever you do, order the truffle fries. I consider myself a french fry connoisseur and these are some of the best I've had. I'm giving it 4 and not 5 because EVERY. SINGLE. DESSERT. has cinnamon, and I'm allergic. I love dessert, and frankly this just isn't necessary. Overall. Fabulous.

Outrageously overpriced. I can only imagine that some of my fellow reviewers were tanked on wine when they wrote their glowing reviews, because the food is downright lousy.   My girlfriend and I had the soup of the day (chicken rice and curry, which was fine), and a decent salad. But then the tapas started. First, green beans, which were in a delicious sauce but were severely undercooked. Then, the flatbread, which is an awful way to waste $17. It was a chewy, flavorless affair that left us salivating for a $2 frozen pizza back at home. Then the Hangar Steak, which was also undercooked, lukewarm, and utterly bland.  It came paired with an unappetizing and -- brace yourself -- undercooked risotto!   Everything needed pepper, yet none was forthcoming.  It seemed the wait staff was too busy obliging other tables' requests to uncork another bottle of wine.   With drinks and tip, we taught ourselves a $95 lesson: don't eat here again.
We went here last week with another couple. Most of the food was tasty but some weren't that great for me. It was loud and hard to hear the server, and the service was very slow.

I went here with a group of 10 and spent two hours enjoying food and drink! Everything we ordered was amazing and we tried A LOT of things. To name a few - the potstickers, the duck confit spring rolls, the thai flatbread, the veggie flatbread, the calamari, the truffle fries, the cheese plate, the green beans, the bruschetta, the pork tenderloin, the crab cakes, the tomato bisque, and several desserts. Everything comes out beautifully prepared and there was nothing that disappointed. It was a feast! We also tasted many different wines and cocktails and no one had any complaints there either. I am not a wine connoisseur, but the Pinot Grigio that I had was just fine. The place was packed, but we had a reservation and our table was ready when we arrived. Parking is a bit of a problem, but there is valet parking and parking across the street. Surprisingly, the desserts were our least favorite items. We tasted the warm chocolate cake, the bread pudding, fruit tart and peach cobbler. They were all "OK" but just didn't measure up to the savory dishes. Our servers were attentive and friendly and kept the food coming and cleared the dishes in a timely manner. I will definitely return to try the few items we didn't try!  Be prepared to part with some cash, but at least you are getting a good return on your money!

It just isn't very good. The menu felt like we were eating someplace 15 years ago. Essentially a mix of bread, cheese and meat, with limited veg. That's in theory fine, but nothing felt particularly fresh... and with such an odd mix of flavor profiles, it doesn't work. Had some fine wine, but nothing special. The person in our group who suggested giving it a shot ended up apologizing at the end of the night.

This place had earned a reputation for being a "cougar bar", but we just re-visited recently and fell in love with it again.  My tip: go on a week night for fabulous happy hour specials!  Sure it gets busy in there and you may have to wait to find a table, but people watching is part of the fun isn't it?  We didn't have much issue and our table ordered a bunch of apps to sample and share...we loved the spicy green beans and the shrimp and andouille pizza was spectacular!  Will be back again soon...maybe sitting outside next time!

Great place!  Pretty slow, as you might expect on a Monday night.  Had nice Malbec, great marinaded olives and a perfect-sized sausage and mushroom pizza.    Decor is very spiffy.  Rather hard to find the place if you're not a local.  Little strip mall right behind the tire store.  Look Arden, as it's worth searching for.  Get in here!!
Love it, Love it, Love it.  Haven't taken anyone there who didn't say the same.  Food is great, infused martini's fabulous and the wine list extensive.  Go!

I usually don't go to restaurants outside of the Madison downtown area, but I came here for a work event and will definitely be going back! The food and ambience are great. The food is meant to share so don't go if you're they type of person who doesn't like sharing. I took away 1 star for two reasons: 1. It's a bit loud in there so it's sort of hard to have a conversation when you're sitting across the table from someone and 2. Usually at a tapas style restaurant, they will change your plates in the middle so sauce and stuff doesn't have to get on the next food you eat. They didn't do that (and the plates were pretty tiny). Other than that, I highly recommend this restaurant!

Took hubby here for his birthday.  It was FABULOUS! We had: Seared Sesame Tuna Sweet Chili Calamari Fries Labelle Farm Foie Gras Center Cut Filet OMG. Sooo freaking good!!  We will definitely be back!
